ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Given the presence of anhydrous ammonia, P&O Cold Logistics has in place a Process Safety Management program to ensure the safety of employees and the general public in the vicinity.  This program addresses items related to the operation of ammonia based refrigeration systems including but not limited to the handling of the chemical, operator training, equipment selection and maintenance, contractor qualifications, preventative maintenance programs, routine and emergency operating procedures and emergency planning and response.  P&O Cold Logistics also has an emergency action plan in effect, which is designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.


Ammonia has a strong pungent odor which is detectable at very low concentration levels when released to the atmosphere.  The refrigeration system is designed such that under normal operating conditions, no ammonia is released to the atmosphere.  However, unforseen circumstances or system upset could lead to leakage of a portion of the ammonia from the system.  Given the strong odor of ammonia, even a small quantity of released ammonia will be detected at some distance from the source of the leak.  Ammonia is detectable by its odor at levels well below that which will raise health concerns.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Construction of the ammonia refrigeration system expansion project at P&O Cold Logistics was completed in October 2001.  The facility is located on a 28 acre site, southeast of the intersection of North Broadway and Barbours Cut Streets in the city of La Porte, Texas.  The complex includes a large cold storage warehouse building with auxiliary office space.  The  warehouse is refrigerated using anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  The system was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, st

ate, and local regulations including the Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes.

The ammonia refrigeration system uses 30,000 pounds of ammonia for storage freezers and dock operations.  The majority of the system is located in the machine room including vessels and compressors.  The condensers are mounted on the roof, and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold areas or rooftop penthouses.


HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

*  Worst Case Release Result Summary

      Scenario Description:  Release of the maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the largest vessel - 14,472 pounds in 10 minutes.  The worst case scenario is very unlikely as it assumes the total and catastrophic failure of a vessel containing ammonia in its most volatile state.  Since this vessel is enclosed by the machine room, passive mitigation effects were taken into consideration when determining the release rate to the outside atmosphere.  The most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used: 1.5 meters per second wind speed, and F stability.  The Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.  This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.

Note: Item 2.5 is rounded to two significant figures and 2.6 is rounded to one significant figure per EPA's instructions.

*  Alternative Release Result Summary

     Scenario Description: A release of ammonia from resulting from a 1/4 inch diameter hole in a pipe.  The release rate of ammonia due to the pressure of the tank is 122 pounds per minute (Note: Item 3.5 is rounded to two significant figures and 3.6 is rounded to one significant figure per EPA's instructions).  This release could occur due to a gasket rupture, pinhole leak, flange seal leak, valve bonnet leak, etc.  In addition, this release could occur outside, t

herefore, no passive mitigation measures were considered.  The meteorological conditions used were 3.0 meters per second wind speed, and D stability.  The Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.  This release reaches off site and may impact other commercial/industrial neighbors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The P&O Cold Logistics ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. 

The Process Safety Management program ensures that all security and safety procedures are addressed.  Staff are trained in operation, maintenance and emergency procedures related to the operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  All refrigeration equipment and ammonia vessels are equipped with automatic pressure safety relief devices to prevent pressure build-up beyond safe equipment operation levels.  A preventative maintenance program assures that equipment is maintained an serviced on a regular schedule and that worn, ageing, or defective components are replaced as required to maintain equipment in good operating condition.  Controls and safety devices are tested regularly to ensure proper operation.

In addition to the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Within the past five years (October 1996 - October 2001), the facility has not had an accidental release of ammonia causing personnel injury or with off site consequences.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The P&O Cold Logistics has a Response Plan for On-Site Emergency Operations.  This Plan outlines the policies and procedur

es in place to respond to potential ammonia alarms or releases.  The facility has several trained personnel to assist in an orderly evacuation as well as to diagnose the alarm condition.  

The Response Plan for On-Site Emergency Operations includes the facility emergency coordinators, the staff alerting list, emergency notification list, and the hazardous material agency notification and procedures.  This Plan then proceeds to detail the procedures for employees and management in the event of a fire, evacuation, compressor room shut down, blackout, and ammonia release/clean-up.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis and Hazard Assessment (Off-Site Consequence Analysis) provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the P&O Cold Logistics facility.  Many of the recommendations will be implemented prior to completion of the expansion project with the remaining being completed by 4/1/2002. 

A01  Check PSV replacement schedule to determine if PSVs for existing equipment should be replaced as part of the expansion project.

R01  Consider using an outside alarm company to monitor the system for ammonia leaks, high levels in vessels, and other ammonia refrigeration system alarm conditions.

R02  Consider programming the ammonia detection and computer control system as follows for the engine room ammonia sensor (per Chapter 11 of the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code):
1.  Alarm at 25 ppm (PEL);
2.  Energize Emergency Ventilation System at 50% IDLH (150 ppm); and
3.  De-energize electrical power to engine room at 25% LEL (40,000 ppm) or less.

R03  Update the Operating Procedures to incorporate operating the spring loaded valve and globe valve in series. Verify that the spring-loaded valve is equipped with a relief.

R04  Incorporate the use of a face shield into the Operating Procedures for draining oil as additional personal protective equipment. 

R05  Install spring-loaded valves on all other (existing) oil pots and follow the management of chan

ge procedures. 

R06  Determine the concentration at which the ammonia sensor located in the relief valve pipeline header will alarm (i.e. 100 ppm - 500 ppm). 

R07  Install an eye wash station outside engine room door that leads to the outside of the building.

R08  Consider providing the First Responder - Technician Level training (24 hour with 8 hour refresher) to facility personnel.

R09  Investigate which agency will respond in the event of a release of ammonia and how long it will take for that agency to reach the facility.  Consider inviting agency to conduct an emergency response  drill on site.

R10  Consider obtaining a hand held ammonia detector to use during maintenance to ensure that the ammonia concentration in the area is less than the IDLH (300 ppm).  

R11  Consider obtaining an exhaust ventilation fan to reduce the ammonia concentration during maintenance procedures. 

R12  Consider installing a temperature indicator in the main liquid line.

R13  Compare the pressure transducer reading with the pressure gage on the high pressure receiver level port periodically. Include this check in the Mechanical Integrity program.

R14  Install check valve on charging line.

R15  Obtain the supplier's (La Roche) delivery procedures and update the delivery procedures outlined in the PSM Operating Procedures.

R16  Update the PSM Operating Procedures to include the corporate line opening permit policy.

R17  Review the five year independent inspection criteria outlined in the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration Bulletin 110.

R18  Include exercising lag pump in Mechanical Integrity section of the PSM/RMP and testing that the lead-and-lag switch functions properly.

R19  Include in the Mechanical Integrity program to annually drain the -40  F recirculator.  Prepare a procedure.

R20  Install an oil/water separation vessel for draining the -40  F recirculator and for draining oil from all oil pots in the system. The suction should go back to the -40  F

recirculator.  Need operating procedure for oil/water separation vessel.

R21  Ensure that there is a separate operating procedures for this oil pot because high pressure vapor is used to pressurize tank. (Isolate / open hot gas / bleed vent valve.)

R22  Add a back-pressure relief regulator in the equalizing line from the oil pot to the -40  F recirculator and a pressure gage on the oil pot.

R23  Install a 0.5 inch line from the pump discharge to the float column for all three recirculators to allow the operators to test the level float/column alarms and switches.

R24  Test float column alarms and switches annually (on all vessels).

R25  Install an interlock between the  operating level and the transfer pump to ensure that you don't drain the vessel with manual override. 

R26  Prepare an operating procedure for operation of the -40  F transfer pump. 

R27  The relief regulator vent piping for the -20  F Freezer Evaporators should be sent back to the intermediate suction (intercooler).

R28   Move hot gas pilot line downstream of the hot gas isolation valve H-1. (Or move H-1 upstream of the pilot line.)  Remove H-1 in pilot line too.

R29  Consider the feasibility of sensors outside by the valve stations (i.e conduct an experiment with one sensor for the new side to see how it works).  These sensors would be interlocked to either shut down the pumps for the respective recirculator or, due to the low temperature /pressure, the sensor could close the hot gas king valve.

R30  Verify that if there is a release on the roof, the ammonia detector inside the penthouse will shut off the pumps and main hot gas king solenoid valve. 

R31  Install a 0.5 inch solenoid bypass around the main hot gas solenoid to soften the flow.

R32  Consider altering the defrost cycle so that it only occurs during business hours (between 5 am and 6 pm while operators are on site).  Modify timer so that they by-pass solenoid is opened first, then once the line is pressurized, open the mai

n hot gas solenoid to charge the hot gas line once each day.  There are many outstanding issues associated with defrost:
1.  How often is defrost required (seasonal)?
2.  How will the hot gas line drains/soft close?
3.  What are the plans for existing defrost (demand defrost versus a set schedule)? (Currently no record of room defrost.)

R33  Conduct the visual inspection of the evaporator valve stations three-times per week (M-W-F).

R34  Update the current daily walk-down sheet to include the M-W-F evaporator valve station inspection. 

R35  Ensure that a calibration / test schedule for the ammonia sensors is included in the Mechanical Integrity section (follow existing P&O Cold Logistics policy).

R36  Remove gages from the relief regulators on the evaporator suction return pipeline and insert a plug in the gage port. Maintain two or three stainless steel gages as spare-parts so that the operators can calibrate, inspect, etc. 

R37  Consider installing a pressure  gage at the main hot gas solenoid bleed valve and manually monitor it on a period basis.

R38  Need to investigate operation of the soft-close, especially, while all evaporators are on the same defrost schedule.

R39  Include on the M-W-F inspection schedule to ensure that the evaporator components are operating properly. Proper draining of defrost condensate pan/line should also be checked (i.e. heat tape, insulation, etc.) during the M-W-F inspection.

R40  Consider installing a permanent eye wash / safety shower on the roof.  Also obtain two portable kits to take to other areas (include the P&O eyewash policy and buddy system policy in the Mechanical Integrity section of the documentation).

R41  Prepare a formal emergency response policy for hurricane.  Include system pump-down and compressor shut down in policy. Also consider isolating the vessels prior to leaving in the event of a hurricane warning.

R42  There will be a keyed bypass for manual defrost which could be done by a non-operator person.

Typically, they defrost while they unload the cell.  Need to review schedules to see how this will work.

R43  Implement SOP for hand valve in Thermosyphon Return relief line - it should be locked open.

R44  Ensure that there is a drain valve off the thermosyphon oil cooler similar to the high stage compressors.

R45  Ensure operator training covers the problems associated with overfilling.

R46  Include in Mechanical Integrity program to change compressor oil filter as needed based on pressure drop or at least annually.

R47  Implement a certification for ammonia refrigeration operators that were employed prior to June 1999 to serve as the initial training documentation (Grandfather clause). 

R48  Need to document new operator on-the-job training. 

R49  Determine the policy for the appropriate personal protective equipment necessary for changing the coalescer oil.

R50  Consider changing the existing pressure relief valve to the appropriate ASME liquid pressure relief valve. 

R51  Prepare an operating procedure for changing the parameters of the high stage compressors.

R52  Verify the actuation pressure of the relief valves at the condensers is 300 psig.

R53  Prepare a startup procedure that describes the steps to be taken in the event that the system can not be started because there is no level in the thermosyphon.

R54  Prepare criteria for manual purging and an operating procedure.  (This procedure should be a generic and used as a guideline so that in the event manual purging is required, operators have a starting point.)

R55  Consider installing a walkway and railing around the new condenser.

R56  Consider installing a walkway and railing around the existing condenser.

R57  Consider moving the pressure relief valves associated with the vessels to a more convenient location (i.e. not over the center of the vessel)  Check code requirements regarding length and diameter of pipe leading to relief valve.

R58  Review the facility for confined spaces and

implement as appropriate.

R59  Overhaul the auto purger prior to starting the new freezer.

R60  Review signs around the engine room and shop area and add warning and ammonia signs as needed.  Consider also adding Authorized Personnel signs as well.

R61  Perform maintenance on emergency exit signs throughout the facility to ensure that all are properly illuminating.

R62  Consider posting bi-lingual warning signs.

R63  Post emergency telephone numbers at key locations throughout the facility.

R64  Verify that emergency response notification and reporting training has been provided to the bi-lingual workforce in Spanish as well as English.  Ensure that documentation is available.
